This was an incredible movie.  The fact that the character development was so strong was unexpected.  This got me interested in Kyokushin Karate...I've practiced over 10 different styles, but now focus on kung fu, TKD, hapkido, aikido and bagua zhang.
One of the main bad guys looks like the singer from Fine Young Cannibals.
DO NOT SKIP THIS MOVIE!
Awesome movie! Similar in theme to IP man. The fight sequences were very realistic too.
There are lot of historical inaccuracy in the depiction of founder of the Kyokushin Kai Kan Karate Sosai Masutatsu Oyama. However, the movie is well built as a story.
This was a captivating Martial Arts film in the tradition of Yip Man.  Excellently done! Great story! Outstanding film.  I loved this film, and rank it as one of the best that I have ever seen.
Well made, excellent.

Martial Arts movie enthusiasts will love this historically inaccurate but well choreographed movie that superficially addresses the life of Mas Oyama. If you want an accurate biography of the karate innovator, do not watch this movie. However, if you like a good story with close to realistic martial arts, enjoy this yarn. One should consider this flick a terrific graphic novel brought to the screen. Nuff said.

THE BEST MARTIAL ARTS MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN

This is probably the best martial arts movie I have ever seen...bar none.  First of all the KOREAN FILM INDUSTRY is technically proficient and that excellence is reflected in this film...unlike the old BRUCE LEE /CHUCK NORRIS films which are at a  more elemental level of film making IMHO.

There is a lot of cultural conflict going on which an OCCIDENTAL can not fully understand ( reasons being  inability to understand the language spoken in the film,  probable lack of nuance in the subtitle translation, lack of focus on this historical aspect in our high schools & college curricula )  .  For instance, this film takes place in Japan right during and after the end of WWII.  It shows the racism KOREANS experienced at the hands of the JAPANESE.  Although  I can not fully understand all the nuances  this historical revelation is fascinating nonetheless.

This film is a biography( fictionalized according to WICK)  of MAS OYAMA a  real  live TAEKWANDO icon; and founder of the ubiquitous eponymously named  TAEKWANDO schools in the USA .  Practitioners of TAEKWANDO will get even more out of this film.  But, I loved it.  Having a background in TAI CHI this film resonated with me.  THE BOOK OF 5 RINGS by MIYAMOSO MUSASHI  is the protagonist's bible.  The protagonist goes into isolation in a harsh environment.  Without being a spoiler...you will love this part.  A series of martial arts challenges are  laid down.  You have to watch to find out what happens in these many challenges.  Finally,  I would be remiss if I failed to mention the love interest angle.  Yoko is a beautiful Japanese geisha.  Our hero plays the  chivalrous Sir Galahad.  Love sparks are kindled.  What is special about  love in this movie is the effect love has on a sentient being who is trying to walk the path of a warrior.  You will need to watch the film to see if 1 human can reconcile being an ultimate savage in a fight while reserving a part of himself  as the preserve of love and tenderness.

I owned this movie 5 years ago and loved it.  I played it over and over again.  My opinion has not changed.  This is one of the greatest martial arts films of all time; and very beautifully filmed.  This film  teems with historical relevance.  A must see for martial artists and anyone who likes a dramatic story which reveals the little told  history ( in the USA at least )  of Japanese racism towards Koreans.

I ONLY WISH I COULD GIVE IT A 10 STAR RATING. NO SPOILERS, BUT IN CASE YOU DIDN'T KNOW THIS IS BASED ON AN ACTUAL PERSON'S LIFE, AND WHAT A LIFE IT WAS. GREAT ACTION SCENES AND THE PLOT CONTINUES TO MOVE THRU OUT. DON'T PASS THIS ONE UP. NO WIRE WORK, JUST GOOD OLD FASHIONED MARTIAL ARTS. GREAT FILM, WELL DONE.

This movie is about a Korean copy-cat martial artist following in the footsteps of Japan's Miyamoto Musashi in order to gain recognition and revenge in the WWII era. Action and story are good, but I'm seen this before in other Musashi movies, so there were no surprises. It was a typical "hero survives" tale. It was interesting to see the racial divide between Koreans living in Japan, and the director's stance on Americans at that time as well. Well worth the watch, even if it is slow going the first 5th of the film.

As others have said, not a realistic portrayal but much more accurate with fighting than most. I have belts in TKD, Praying Mantis (Northern) Kung Fu, and now the past 6 years in Aikido. Fights are not all pretty and flowing like you see in Americanized martial arts flicks or even the popularized Donnie Yen. This is more believable and therefore enjoyable to watch with the exception of one Kendo fight.

Great intention, but terribly clichd.  Obviously written simply to showcase martial arts and Japanese prejudice against Koreans, with some anti-American sentiment thrown in.  Very odd that one of the main Korean protagonists would cite Miyamoto Musashi and the "Book of Five Rings", when a major theme of the movie is struggling for a sense of Korean cultural identify.  Certainly the script writers could have done some research and cited the Korean Hwarang warrior-philosopher Won Gwang Beop Sa, the buddhist monk who taught the youth of the Hwarang Taek Kyong, which is featured in the movie.  And for the record -- I respect Musashi's book and record and am not Korean or Korean-American -- my ancestors were Scots.

Good fighting, choreography, and mix of humor with Eastern humiliation.  Very impressed with the cinematography in Fighter In The Wind.  The film includes Several unbelievable scenes, as do most Kung Fu films.  This film, however, excels in philosophical explanation of Japanese and Korean views on martial arts.  The plot unfolds in some surprising ways.  The life purpose of the main character caught my attention.  Yet, I do not believe making one's aim to become the greatest fighter in the world even at the cost of losing one's loved ones and turning back on commitments is a worthy principle to follow.  Likely, some will not have an issue with the values in the film.  Some scenes are not suitable for kids.  Yes, I'm a parent.

As inaccurate as this movie is about the life of Mas Oyama, it has some fantastic storytelling and fights. The story is about lots of things. Japanese arrogance toward other Asian races, American occupation of Japan after WWII etc. This all acts as a backdrop for the fights the main character ends up in. The fights are actually very realistic. You aren't going to dodge every hit, block everything, magically avoid being cut by a knife etc. In a real fight you'll get tossed around, get punched, hit, whacked with a stick, cut with a knife and this movie portrays that. What makes Mas Oyama's brand of Karate unique is that it focuses on real fighting. You take a hit and keep going until your opponent can no longer attack you. It's gritty, real, focused, and powerful.

Not entirely accurate but it was a  good way to know that SK film industry made it very entertaining and at least see portions of Mas Oyamas struggle to become a better person.  I was a student of Kyokushin when I was 15 years old and competed few times and my final competition was in Japan at a younger age of 23. I lost in quarterfinals because I broke 2 portions of my right ribs during that fight and I ended my training after. To make story short, now Im 48 years old the effects are still lingering.  After watching the movie, I relieved the training during my Kyokushin years.  Thank you.
